snippet: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Friday, selections include an easy and free way to file tax returns that has been fought for years by Intuit, a chart showing many of Am...
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Friday, selections include an easy and free way to file tax returns that has been fought for years by Intuit, a chart showing many of Amazon’s acquisitions and a museum-quality exhibit of Apple material that will appear at the Vintage Computer Festival Southeast in April.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: Ugly Photos, and Delivery by Google

snippet: Facebook will introduce a special version of Google’s Android software system next week that is modified to put the social network front and center on a smartphone.
abstract: Facebook will introduce a special version of Google’s Android software system next week that is modified to put the social network front and center on a smartphone.

headline.main: New Phone by Facebook to Showcase Its Network
headline.print_headline: New Phone By Facebook To Showcase Its Network

byline.original: By BRIAN X. CHEN and NICK BILTON

snippet: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg called the field of politicians jockeying to replace him “really depressing” after hearing them lay out their platforms to improve public safety in New York City.
abstract: Mayor Michael R Bloomberg says the seven leading candidates to replace him as mayor of New York City in 2013 are 'really depressing' and have yet to address the important issues facing the city.

headline.main: Mayor Says ’13 Hopefuls Haven’t Won Him Over
headline.print_headline: Mayor Says ’13 Hopefuls Haven’t Won Him Over

snippet: A study of the nutritional quality of children’s meals at the nation’s largest chain restaurants showed little improvement in the last four years.
abstract: Study commissioned by Center for Science in the Public Interest finds that 91 percent of meals for children at nation's largest chain restaurants fall short of nutritional standards set by National Restaurant Association's Kids LiveWell program, indicating that little progress has been made since previous study in 2008.

headline.main: Most Children’s Meals at Large Restaurant Chains Are Still Unhealthy, a Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Most Children’s Meals at Large Restaurant Chains Are Still Unhealthy, a Study Finds

keywords.value: Center for Science in the Public Interest

headline.main: Spare Times for Children for March 29-April 4

snippet: Analysts find encouragement that the company, fighting to revive its once-dominant brand, is “not bleeding to death.”
abstract: BlackBerry reports surprise fourth-quarter profit of $98 million, or 19 cents a share, following introduction of new line of phones and software; company still records annual net loss of $646 million amid continued decline in sales.

headline.main: A Surprise Quarterly Profit for BlackBerry
headline.print_headline: A Surprise Quarterly Profit for BlackBerry
